com.vaadin.contrib.gwtgraphics.client
Class DrawingArea

java.lang.Object
  com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.UIObject
      com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.Widget
          com.vaadin.contrib.gwtgraphics.client.DrawingArea
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasAllMouseHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasClickHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasMouseDownHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasMouseMoveHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasMouseOutHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasMouseOverHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasMouseUpHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasMouseWheelHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.shared.HasHandlers, com.google.gwt.user.client.EventListener, VectorObjectContainer
public class DrawingArea
extends com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.Widget
implements VectorObjectContainer, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasClickHandlers, com.google.gwt.event.dom.client.HasAllMouseHandlers

The following example shows how a DrawingArea instance is created and added to a GWT application. A rectangle is added to this DrawingArea instance. When the user clicks this rectangle its color changes. 

 DrawingArea canvas = new DrawingArea(200, 200);
 RootPanel.get().add(canvas);
 
 Rectangle rect = new Rectangle(10, 10, 100, 50);
 canvas.add(rect);
 rect.setFillColor("blue");
 rect.addClickHandler(new ClickHandler() {
        public void onClick(ClickEvent event) {
                Rectangle rect = (Rectangle) event.getSource();
                if (rect.getFillColor().equals("blue")) {
                        rect.setFillColor("red");
                } else {
                        rect.setFillColor("blue");
                }
        }
 });

Author:
Henri Kerola / IT Mill Ltd

getRendererString

public java.lang.String getRendererString()
Returns a String that indicates what graphics renderer is used. This String is "VML" for Internet Explorer and "SVG" for other browsers.

Returns:
the used graphics renderer
